title: How to Bracket Photos With a Nikon D70

steps.headline: Have the right type of scene/photo.
steps.description: It will need to be a static or still shot.

steps.headline: Be sure that your camera is in manual mode (P, S, A, or M).
Decide on the type of bracketing (Custom 12).
steps.description:
AE & Flash
AE only
Flash only
White Balance

steps.headline: Set the camera to bracket.
steps.description:
Hold down the bracket icon   while at the same time turning the command dial. Do this until the BKT shows up. Go to the custom menu  and selection 9 to choose if the bracketing will be for WB, 1/2 or 1/3 stops. Choose which order to take your shot in. You can decide between:
MTR > Under > Over
Under > MTR > Over
The choice doesn't matter. Do what works best for you and be sure that you do it the same way each time (although your metadata will tell you which photo is which).

steps.headline: Set the number of exposures and compensation.
steps.description: Hold down the BKT button and rotate the sub-command dial. It is in the front of the camera.

steps.headline: Take your shots.
steps.description: You will need to press the shutter for the number of times that you want to bracket.

steps.headline: Process your photo.
steps.description: Things you can do with multiple identical photos, is create an HDR photograph or choose between the various exposures or white balance for the better photograph.

steps.headline: Switch bracketing off.
steps.description: Hold down the BKT button and rotate the main command dial until it is no longer on the screen.

text:
Identify what is where.  Have the right type of scene/photo. It will need to be a static or still shot. Be sure that your camera is in manual mode (P, S, A, or M).  Decide on the type of bracketing (Custom 12). AE & Flash
AE only
Flash only
White Balance Set the camera to bracket. Hold down the bracket icon   while at the same time turning the command dial. Do this until the BKT shows up. Go to the custom menu  and selection 9 to choose if the bracketing will be for WB, 1/2 or 1/3 stops. Choose which order to take your shot in. You can decide between:
MTR > Under > Over
Under > MTR > Over
The choice doesn't matter. Do what works best for you and be sure that you do it the same way each time (although your metadata will tell you which photo is which). Set the number of exposures and compensation. Hold down the BKT button and rotate the sub-command dial. It is in the front of the camera. Take your shots. You will need to press the shutter for the number of times that you want to bracket. Download your photographs.  Process your photo. Things you can do with multiple identical photos, is create an HDR photograph or choose between the various exposures or white balance for the better photograph. Switch bracketing off. Hold down the BKT button and rotate the main command dial until it is no longer on the screen.
